qas.question: What was the original definition of a cardinal priest?
What name was interpreted as meaning a cardinal who is of the order of popes?

plausible_answers.text: certain key priests of important churches of the Diocese of Rome

qas.question: What does the name "cardinal popes" originally refer to?
What is the name of the important nuns that are chosen by the pope to advice him?
Who holds the title Cardinal of Rome?
What term did not gradually become exclusive to Rome to indicate those entrusted with electing the pope?

context: In modern times, the name "<b1_0><b3_0><b5_0>cardinal priest<b5_0/><b3_0/><b1_0/>" is interpreted as meaning a cardinal who is of the order of priests. Originally, however, this referred to <b2_0>certain key priests of important churches of the Diocese of Rome<b2_0/>, who were recognized as the cardinal priests, the important <a0_0>priests chosen by <b4_0>the pope<b4_0/><a0_0/> to advise him in his duties as Bishop of Rome (the Latin cardo means "hinge"). Certain clerics in many dioceses at the time, not just that of Rome, were said to be the key personnel — the term gradually became exclusive to Rome to indicate those entrusted with electing the bishop of Rome, the pope.
